posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
660g milk, 150g white sugar, 15g skim milk powder, 50g dextrose, 5g xantham gum or guar gum, 40g dark cocoa powder, 80g hazelnut paste

Milk in double boiler, medium heat. While it warms, mix the dry ingredients to combine. When the milk reaches 40 celsius, whisk in all ingredients and bring it up to 65 celsius. Hold temperature for 30 minutes, whisking every 5 minutes.

Cool back to around 40 celsius as quickly as you can (put it in a steel bowl and put that in tub of chilled water or ice), then transfer to the freezer to bring down to 4 celsius, giving it a stir every ten minutes, then put in the fridge to sit for 2 to 4 hours. Don't skip this, the mix is still in the process of chemical transference. Optionally put in the freezer for the final 20 minutes to reduce the time in the ice maker. There's a risk of ice crystals forming if it's in the machine too long.

Start the ice cream maker, while the reservoir cools give the mix blend for a minute, then put it in the maker and let it get to -4 celsius. At this point it should be mixed enough and you can put it in the freezer for a couple of hours to finish freezing. Or you can just be impatient and do it all the way in the maker. Or put half in the freezer and leave half in the maker to compare the difference.

It doesn't really, no, and to be honest, I think all the Mexican Knorr's suck except the shrimp one and the tomato chicken one and even there, Consmate makes a better instant tomato stock than Knorr does, IMO. >>18900636
>Could I still gong fu brew it with a gawain like
A cheap porcelain gaiwan is all you really need. Yixing maybe makes a slight difference but it is not work worrying about when starting out.

>If i keep the boxes I have closed and outside of light they should last a long time right?
Those teas should be fine indefinitely if they came sealed up well. You could stick the boxes in a ziplock bags for additional protection if you want. How did the tea come stored in the boxes?

>>18900733
>Is an electric kettle with a temperature setting where it can keep the water at a certain temp necessary?
For puerh boiling or just off boiling water is what is typically used. An electric kettle that you can set to lower temperatures is nice for green tea and being able to keep the water hot is convenient but you don't need one starting out.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18880148
I opened up my first 2018 Taetea V93 tuo tonight. Bought it on Amazon via the official store for pretty cheap. $35.99 USD for 500g.
It pried open easily, despite feeling more compressed than the typical DaYi cake. I've been enjoying it all night. Not in any particularly scientific way, but just enjoying it casually as I would for a daily drinker like I'm hoping this to be.
The first few brews are solid. It's mild and earthy flavor with a hint of roasted nuts. Maybe a little flat to a fault, but it could also be the recent transport through a damn cold winter. I also inexplicably brewed it with a little less material than I usually do. Either way, the flavors of the tea are what you'd expect from a shou of its age, but dialed back compared to a 7572.
From the smell of the leaves, perhaps there's just a little bit of sweetness trying to come out that I haven't found yet. Been playing around 190-200 degrees F.
Not a bad tea at all! Given the price and shipping availability from Amazon, I could see it being a daily work beater. Given the nice little 100g tuos it comes as, it's also the tea I would give to friends getting into the hobby.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: What variety of tea has the highest caffeine and theanine content? I believe the highest for theanine is matcha, but I could be wrong. It's hard getting a straight answer for caffeine though. And I have found articles that contradict each other claiming that young sheng has more then young shou, and vice versa. It doesn't help that most resources are trying to sell me something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18916543
We have much better artificial sources for both, I'd personally drink whatever you want and simply supplement whichever you want more of. For both theanine and caffeine, I believe it's matcha since you ingest the whole leaf. It's difficult to measure because what you actually care about is how much your body absorbs when you drink it. The most L-theanine will be in young shoots harvested in the spring that are steamed. Sencha, gyokuro, and matcha are comparable in this case, puerh seems to have a lower l-theanine content, maybe because of the kill-green. Having said that, the differences are a fraction of the total amount of L-theanine present in the leaves, it doesn't really matter. Having said THAT, we don't actually even care, because how much L-theanine is present in the leaves doesn't really tell us anything. Again, matcha wins here (gram for gram) because you eat the whole leaf. However, I drink thirty or so grams of tea a day, and I doubt you will be consuming an equivalent amount of matcha.

tl;dr too many confounding factors just take L-theanine or caffeine if you want more of either. If not, just drink tea and stop worrying about it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18916543
Caffeine content in tea is all over the place, impossible to say one type has more caffeine then others, varietal, harvest season, and environment probably have the largest effects on caffeine content. How the tea is processed (black, green etc) doesn't change the amount of caffeine in the leaves

>>18916670
I just drink a lot of tea and read a lot about tea, I'm also sort of into nutrition for other reasons so I know a bit about that too. There's very little hard data, a lot of statements on effects are total guesswork. I'm not into any of the mystical tea nonsense, but subjectively I would say that young sheng, especially forest tea (of any age) has a stronger feeling than most other tea. This is broadly what people mean when they talk about Cha Qi, literally the Qi of the tea. It's not reducible to simply caffeine + theanine, I've taken exceptional amounts of both in isolation, and with other tea, and haven't been able to duplicate the effect. Whatever it is, it seems to affect people differently. Some people are really into it though, and you'll see people look for and pay a premium for tea with good "Qi".

If you're not used to drinking high quality tea, 14 grams of sheng is a fair bit, I built up tolerance pretty fast, but some people seem to not ever build up much tolerance at all.

>>18918124
So many basic repetitive tasks still done by humans. I'm shocked they don't have a robot de-veiner + de-sheller -- I assumed that would have been everywhere for decades by now, since every shrimp product would use it.

A $10m R&D + buy investment on a new robot that replaces 100 jobs pays for itself in East Asia in 10 years on wages alone (and labor is more than just wages). Combine the development of multiple shrimp handling tasks for ready food production and you bring the unit costs down significantly. You'll still need staff to handle pieces rejected by the robot, but even if it cuts staff 50% it would be a crazy good investment if you plan on keeping your company for a decade. My cost estimate for a shrimp robot may be wildly optimistic, however.

>>18919101
As long as the meat gets to 75c it's safe. it will get to that temp with a proper kebab cooker and waiting the correct amount of time for the outside layer to come to temp.
The most dangerous things for food safety in a kebab shop are:
1) A busy period where the workers go through too much kebab meat and get into meat that's in the food safety danger zone and don't use an additional cooking step to bring it up to temp by finishing it off on a hotplate
2) Failing to maintain temperature controls when approaching the end of the kebab or before closing time, example in the last hour of service, the final parts of the kebab are cut & cooked on a hotplate then transferred to a bain marie to keep temp but the bain marie isn't set correctly or is malfunctioning, creating a danger area.
3) Contamination of the kebab knife/shaver coming into contact with raw meat, blood drippings.
4) Cross contamination of vegetables/sauces by someone doing multiple jobs without cleaning, using the same counter or cutlery/tongs/knives for meat & vegetables.
5) Bad temperature control of cold salad/sauces.

I put spray cheese on almost everything I eat. I've can't remember the last time I've eaten in at a fast food place because they don't have spray cheese as a condiment. Even if it makes more sense for my schedule to eat in at a fast food place, I won't unless I remembered to bring a can of spray cheese in my car, and even then, I'll eat it in the car to save myself the embarrassment of having to show the entire restaurant my spray cheese.

A while back, I had to go to a really fancy restaurant for a family get-together, and I was nearly kicked out by the waitstaff for "ruining the atmosphere" when I put spray cheese on my steak tartare. After nearly getting on my knees while apologizing, they let me stay to finish the meal, but it was extremely uncomfortable, especially since there wasn't anything on the menu that could satisfy my particular palate. I'm pretty sure I could hear some waitresses giggling from the kitchen when I passed by it to go to the bathroom.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not some white trash redneck who can't cook. I really like copying Alton Brown and Adam Rageusa, often to the letter, but no matter what they make, I WILL spray cheese it. I can't live without it.

posts.com:
I put spray cheese on almost everything I eat. I've can't remember the last time I've eaten in at a fast food place because they don't have spray cheese as a condiment. Even if it makes more sense for my schedule to eat in at a fast food place, I won't unless I remembered to bring a can of spray cheese in my car, and even then, I'll eat it in the car to save myself the embarrassment of having to show the entire restaurant my spray cheese.

A while back, I had to go to a really fancy restaurant for a family get-together, and I was nearly kicked out by the waitstaff for "ruining the atmosphere" when I put spray cheese on my steak tartare. After nearly getting on my knees while apologizing, they let me stay to finish the meal, but it was extremely uncomfortable, especially since there wasn't anything on the menu that could satisfy my particular palate. I'm pretty sure I could hear some waitresses giggling from the kitchen when I passed by it to go to the bathroom.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not some white trash redneck who can't cook. I really like copying Alton Brown and Adam Rageusa, often to the letter, but no matter what they make, I WILL spray cheese it. I can't live without it.

>>18912197
The sign is a subtle joke. The shop is called "Sneed's Feed & Seed", where feed and seed both end in the sound "-eed", thus rhyming with the name of the owner, Sneed. The sign says that the shop was "Formerly Chuck's", implying that the two words beginning with "F" and "S" would have ended with "-uck", rhyming with "Chuck". So, when Chuck owned the shop, it would have been called "Chuck's Fuck and Suck".

posts.com:
There are four things you need for a good burger:

1. Decent beef. This should be self explanatory but the number of dumbfucks who buy cheap ground beef is amazing.
2. Fat. Do not use lean beef. You want *at least* an 80/20 ratio. Add fat, if you must.
3. A good sear. Doubly true if you're doing a smash burger, obviously.
4. Season the outside of the patty when it it is in the pan: salt & black pepper. Ignore all the retards ITT telling you to add onion powder or Worcestershire or whatever. You're making a burger, not meatloaf. Oh and DEFINITELY no egg or breadcrumbs in a beef patty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Elitists will tell you hurr durr no seasoning but this can turn any quality beef into a tasty burger.
I've also noticed that store brand american cheese is absolute garbage and significantly worse than craft singles which are significantly worse than anything like Sargento or deli cheese. The cheese quality is arguably more important for a "cheese burger" if you only have offbrand cheese product just toss it and top your burger with something else.
I also prefer grilling to pan seared unless I'm doing Oklahoma onion/ smash burgers.
You can cut the onions into slices, season and grill those too. A lot less time consuming than waiting for onions to carmalize and you don't need to add any oil or butter. Flip burg 3 times. Large seeded bun if you plan to cover it with veggies and sauces, smaller glossy buns for just cheese and onion.

And no Europoors, a chicken sandwich is not ALWAYS a chicken burger. Only if the chicken is minced/ pressed into a patty.

>>18916264
You want (starting top left to right): 1) small fridge under drying space for shit you cleaned in sink, 2) double sink above cupboards for trash can, detergents, cleaning products 3) stove 4) cupboards with heavy pots, pans, utensils, mandolins, sieves

Then you want a small open space to the side table, that's where you'll eat most of the time.

Your counter comes where you have door and cabinets. You hide it from view (to side table and main table) with cabinets that are substantially higher (like, 1.5m). Put your dishwasher under your counter.

Cutlery, glasses, cups, dishes all go in the cupboards facing the tables. Daily stuff near the side table, fancy stuff near the man table, obviously.

Good luck, you'll need it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18916264
So far OP I'd go with the Triangle in >>18918259
You want the fridge/freezer positioned away away from your cooking range/oven so the coolant and compressor aren't fighting a siege war against entropy and wearing down the appliance motors.
Also PLEASE DON'T JAM THE CABINETS RIGHT UP AGAINST THE FREEZER/FRIDGE. You want to allow some clearance all the way around the side and backs of the appliance for temperature exchange to occur and be able to pull them out to do dust/clean the condenser coils every now and then to keep them running happily.
Like >>18917894 said you need to give us some actual measurements of your floor-space and ideally the major appliances to want included because that will dictate certain choices for you (for example the dishwasher typically is plumbed off the sine hot/cold water line as runs under the sink and if so will sit beside the sink for best efficiency).
You need more counter-space than you anticipate not just for the Mise en place prep surrounding your cook-top (ideally you want it on both sides of the heat like in your GF's example as others mentioned) but because you'll want to over-budget counter-space/wall outlets for certain medium-size semi-fixed kitchen appliances you use often like a microwave, toaster, stand mixer, High-Power Blender like a Vitamix, vaccum sealer for sous vide/Bulk Grocery Re-sealer, etc.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18921878 Contined
Ideally you want some kind of counter/table-space right beside the fridge/freezer so when you are putting away, pulling out, or just re-arranging cold ingredients you minimize travel across the room.
Kitchen islands aren't necessarily a bad fall-back option if permanent counter-space is at a premium after you deduct for the above, but just get one of those large movable stainless steel islands with locking castor wheel feet for maximum clean-up efficiency and positioning flexibility to avoid the issue >>18919424 mentioned. The only advantage to a permanent island is if you plumb a secondary sink in it.
Also consider where your range hood/ventilation makes sense and any windows.
Do you want a nice taller kitchen steel trash with a foot peal can like a Simply Human model or something smaller that's discretely built-in the cabinetry like picrel?
It's better to have cooking utensils drawers right next to the heating element in reach so that you reduce travel when you need to switch from tongs to a spatula or a whisk for example.
Finally consider your kitchen cupboard placement for staples and spices, it MUST be located away from your sources of moisture (sink) and heat (range/oven) to prevent degradation (don't keep your spices on the counter or in a drawer next to the hobs or in a cabinet above the range either as steam rises from above.

>>18918570
>got it, so the solution to bad natural gas stoves is to widen the pipeline of electric and let more juice in? and brownout california thinks this is sustainable?
They are currently importing electricity from other states...states where coal-fired power plants are allowed. It's ridiculous because "importing" electricity over vast distances is actually inefficient. Some energy is lost over distance, and the longer the distances, the more energy is lost, so the power plant has to burn EVEN MORE coal per unit of electricity delivered, the longer the distance. Similar to how lead mining is too costly to do in the USA anymore due to EPA regulations, so we just import all our lead from China, which has no EPA regulations, and which uses vast amounts more energy, per unit of lead, to deliver it to us by sea.

posts.name: Anonymous

Fresh diced onion, fresh garlic but don't add it until the last minute before its done or it'll burn. Lime juice after the garlic and cilantro when its done cooking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18918346
LOTS OF CAYENNE MANY TABLESPOONS

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18918346
For the dry mix:
1 part oregano (mexican if you have it)
2 parts salt
2 parts pepper
2 parts garlic powder
2 parts cumin
2 parts coriander
8 parts chili powder
Add the above to your already browned beef and onion (yes, chop up one yellow onion and cook it with the beef). Now stir in about 4 oz of tomato sauce and 4 oz of chicken broth, then simmer on med-low, stirring occasionally, until it's the right consistency (maybe 30 minutes).

posts.com: Mexicans don’t use ground coriander. If you’re doing just spices go with cumin, oregano, garlic powder, and paprika. You can also add knife chicken bouillon powder instead of salt since every Mexican kitchen uses that. If you want to go further than just spices and use a blender, blend up a tomato, half onion, few cloves of garlic, jalapeño, the spices previously mentioned, and after you sear the ground beef add the blended salsa and cook. Add as much of it as you want depending on how you want the flavor and consistency to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18921622
no technique as far as i can tell. depends on your oven of course, but i do max temp from the start (my oven goes up to about 200-220, no digital dial so can't tell for sure), shallow baking pan (the one that comes with the oven if you have it), spread fries on baking sheet, not even in that autistic way where you make sure they don't overlap, drizzle sunflower oil or olive oil, mix them with my hands until they get reasonably coated and then just wait until they attain the kind of appearance i want. no flipping, just turning the baking pan around in 90 degree increments.

i think they turn out pretty good, as long as you eat them as soon as they're cool enough to eat. in 15-20 minutes they're shit. i season them right before eating with salt and pepper, maybe some lemon juice, maybe some grated parmesan, if i'm feeling fancy.

It's not mayo, it's McChicken sauce.
I even ask for extra McChicken sauce packets and the staff is so friendly and more than willing to oblige.

One time I asked for McChicken sauce packets and they gave me three. I said, "Wow, three for free!" and the nice friendly McDonald's worker laughed and said, "I'm going to call you 3-for-free!".

It's such a fun and cool atmosphere at my local McDonald's restaurant, I go there at least 3 times a week for lunch and a large iced coffee with milk instead of cream, 1-2 times for breakfast on the weekend, and maybe once for dinner when I'm in a rush but want a great meal that is affordable, fast, and can match my daily nutritional needs.

I even dip my fries in McChicken sauce, it's delicious! What a great restaurant.

4lbs of drumsticks
4ish chopped green onions
1 bulb of garlic cut in half or less if you want
2 inch piece of ginger sliced
17 cups of water

Pressure cook for 45 minutes minimum, or 5-6 hours simmered.

The cartilage and large tendon removed goes in stock, I IQF the skins and do various things with them. They can also go in stock, or they can be chicken-fried. I'll post it for him.

Slice the chicken legs along the bottom and peel off the bottom tedons and cartilage. Don't be too concerned with how cleanly it comes off. Just take it off.

Next, pull the skin off. Save the skin for later. It's a valuable piece of food. We don't need it for this, though.

Next, rub down the sexy naked chicken legs with salt. Just salt. This is called dry brining. You're gonna let those legs sit for at least 24 hours in the fridge.

Later on, go ahead and spice them up however you like. We're gonna roast those sons of bitches. Do you know what roasting is?

Roasting is a form of cooking that involves indirect, dry heat. That means not letting it sit on a pan (direct heat) and not covering it in a pot or any other stupid bullshit. You want hot air whipping around your shit. This is not a saute. This is not a braise. This is roasting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So anyway... chicken leg roasting...

It's pretty easy. You can do it with your home oven, it's best if you home oven has a convection setting. That's the best for roasting.

The definition of roasting is surrounding your food in hot, circulation, indirect heat. If you put in on a tray, the tray is direct heat. It heats up and fries part of the meat. You want your meat to be suspended as much as possible, and you want your heat source to be circulated as much as possible... that's what convection setting is. It's basically a fan that blows heated air around your oven.

If you like costco rotisserie chicken, that is roasting. The chickens are suspended by a rotisserie device in a convection oven.

In many comercial restaurants, a roasted meat is hung or suspended in a large convection oven, and it's blasted by hot air. This is roasting... this is he definition of indirect heat.

Everything else might as well be pan-frying. Pan frying has it's place. For lake trout or whatever. Beef steaks are pretty good pan fried.

Roasting is a different thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
is absolutely fucking delicious, and super healthy.

a russian friend of mine introduced me to it. since then i've given up all carbs except buckwheat (and potatoes occasionally).

it's whole grain, it's gluten-free, it taste absolutely delicious (as long as you make sure to put lots of butter/tallow and good amount of salt in).

it's imo the tastiest carb, and one of the healthiest if not the healthiest carb out there.

idk why the health fad is onto quinoa but not buckwheat. quinoa taste like shriveled up rice while buckwheat taste based and wholesome.

it's hard to describe the taste to those of you who haven't tried it. but basically it's similar to rice but it taste more earth-y and wholesome

ez recipe:

1. combine 1 cup of buckwheat, 1.5-2 cups of water (depends on how fluffy you want it), 0.5-1 teaspoon of salt, and a good chunk of butter in a saucepan
2. bring pot to boil, reduce heat to simmer and simmer for 15 mins
3. after 15 mins check the pot - you shouldn't see any visible liquid in there. turn off heat and let sit for 10 minutes.
4. eat. add more butter/salt if you want

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1kg flour
800g (about 5) potatoes mashed
400g butter
50g salt
3 egg yolks
150ml milk
two packets dry yeast.
boil peel and mash the potatoes. yeast goes in the milk with some sugar. flour butter and potatoes combine, and the yeast and milk, yolks, let it mix a minute, add the salt. knead that shit, refrigerate for an hour, roll out 2cm thick, separate into rolls, let rise, brush with egg, bake 200c
>my faggot breadmaker can't fit 2kg of ingredients
sad

>>18909607
>so that should make it much quicker to recoup the cost of the breadmaker
i'll break down the math for you. let's be generous and assume we don't buy $1.75 store brand garbage bread but instead we buy something decent like farmhouse for $4. let's also buy our bread ingredients in bulk to bring the cost of each loaf made down to $1. we save at best $3/loaf so you're payoff time is going to come down to how much bread you actually go through. if you have a family and couple of kids so maybe you go through 2 loaves a week at which point you have a yearly savings of $312/year. that saving can buy you a very nice bread machine and you will get your money back by the end of a year. for me, the savings is only half of that because i only go through one loaf per week at best. do i really want to invest $2-300 if it's going to take me multiple years to break even? meh, guess it depends if i want to pick up a new hobby.

>>18914677
Kroger sells whole buttermilk pretty cheap. Here's my go to:
Preheat oven to 450f (you can go higher but I'm paranoid about fumes, long story) if you're using a dutch oven or it in there now.
500g flour (any kind works, bread flour is unsurprisingly the best.)
10 grams salt
9 grams baking soda
About forty grams of sugar (or honey, or brown sugar. I'm sure maple syrup or jaggery would work)
20oz cold buttermilk (I know I'm mixing unit types, but I have a 20oz cup that I use for this and the grams are correct,I just forget what they are(
Mix the dry shit, pour in the wet shit, but save the cup you had the butter milk in.
When there's no more dry powder either spoon it into a well oiled loaf pan, or put it in a disc shape on baking paper.
Now take the buttermilk cup. There should be liquid that was stuck to the sides. Pour that on top and use the back of your mixing spoon to smooth it out. You can score it but you don't need to, this isn't a kneaded dough. If u are using the Dutch oven, use the paper to transfer the disc. Put the loaf pan or dutch oven in.
At 450f this should take a bit over forty minutes, I generally go 42.
I've lately tried adding baking powder to see what happens. I don't really get more rise, but the bread is a bit softer, but it's fine without it.
Let any bread cool completely before slicing.
Other than preheat and bake time, this only takes me a maybe three minutes.
If I have more time I'll make a kneaded or folded yeast bread.

>>18913183
Anon, as a followup since you may not see this until later: excessively bitter flavors frequently come from overextraction which means you might be brewing your coffee too long. You should consider grinding coarser without changing any other variables and see if that makes a difference. If using espresso, consider pulling a shorter shot without changing grind size or grind coarser to get a faster shot. Either way, the extraction of the beans will be less. Another possibility is that the water temperature may be too high which causes more efficient extraction of bitter compounds in coffee. If varying grind size doesn't solve your issue, consider lowering the water temperature 3-5 degrees or so to see if you move in a good direction and continue until you reach where you want to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18913337
No guarantees this will solve your issue but a broad rule of thumb is that harsh bitter flavors are from overextraction and harsh acidity is from underextraction. If acidity and bitterness are both balanced and there's a pleasant almost sweet taste from the espresso then you're right where you want to be. A general rule of thumb is to get your desired amount of coffee out in approximately 30s, which is a surprisingly long time if you're not used to it. If you want 2:1 (30g espresso out for 15g of coffee in) you may need to grind quite fine. If you find your shots are running quick, then you may need to settle for luongo shots at a 3 or 4:1 ratio until you can dial in your grind for more conventional 1.5-2.5 espresso ratios.

Temperature defects are tough to deal with because typically only really high-end machines will have custom temperature settings. Hoffman says that temp defects are typically not that severe compared to extraction defects so grind size and its effect on shot timing are more important.

Another factor a lot of lower-end machines run into is channeling because the pumps run at too high of pressure. You end up with underextracted and overextracted areas which creates the worst of both worlds. Adding a puck screen in forces even flow over the puck and if your machine is modifiable with an lower-pressure OPV spring (9 bar is considered standard) then I would recommend making that modification because it's easy and cheap to do. My Gaggia runs at 15 bar stock which is way too high, the 9 bar spring will set that as the new upper limit.

>>18913512
Yeah, it just sounds like you want stronger coffee. Simple answer is to use more coffee. If 50g to 500ml is too strong, back it down to 40g/500ml. I do single cup pourovers at 50g/500ml. Thing about these internet guys who do "recipes" is that there's no accounting for taste. Most people prefer a weaker brewed coffee. The important thing to understand is how to change the cup to suit your tastes. Going finer and finer with the grind will eventually give you a more bitter, overextracted cup, yet still be watery. So, go a bit coarser to eliminate fines, steep a bit longer to account for the lessened surface area, use more coffee.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
r8 my method of making coffee
similar concept to french press, but without using an actual french press because it's too much work (and a waste of water and heat and time) to clean several of them per day (family also drink coffee, so thered be so many presses to clean per day it's just dumb, so thats why they use my method now too)

>fold an unbleached filter paper into a tall cone, place it in a mug
>put coffee in (for my usual it's 16g of dark roast)
>boiling water (it cools down immediately by touching the mug so it's never really boiling, so it doesnt 'scald' the coffee)
>for me it's usually ~6 minutes, occasionally longer
carefuly lift the 'bag' (filter paper) out, place a mini sieve on the top of the mug, place the filter paper on that to let the rest flow out into the mug
>after a minute give the 'bag' a good squeeze to squeeze the rest of the roasted bean juice out into the mug
>'wa la'
>no need to wash a french press, just throw the 'bag' into the food waste bin
I add other stuff to make my overall coffee 'drink', but that's not the point, the point here is my brewing method
Different family members use different coffees and make different drinks overall, so different times and different amounts of water, but we all use this same basic brewing method now
Admittedly one drawback is we don't get the oils that we would from a french press, in a french press the oils would flow through, but here the paper filter captures it
So we're missing out on that but that's a worthwhile tradeoff in exchange for not having to wash the presses
Whaddya think?

>"Hurr durr why not just make pourover coffee with those filters?"
I literally have never understood pourover coffee
Every time I tried, the coffee just flows through in seconds
Literally no time for extraction
How can you even make coffee that way?
I'm sure you can make some gay artsy >le floral delicate sour flavours '''coffee''' themed dilute water that way
But not actual coffee
The ultimate meme

Through millions of years of evolution our bodies are naturally attuned to our intuitive dietary intake within our native environment. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I made home-made filet-o-fish a couple of weeks ago.

Ingredients

-wonderbread hamburger bun (contains a lot of datem like a mcdonalds bun)
-van de kamp's frozen minced fish patties of wild caught pollock (same fish as mcdonald's)
-kraft tarter sauce
-field american cheese slice

Steamed the buns in a collander for 2 minutes.
Cheese is set out to get up to room temp and then goes straight on the bun out of the steamer, one half slice per sandwich
Pattie goes on the bun right after taking out of the oven.
Tartar sauce squeezed in a cup to get up to room temp before putting the fish in the oven, now slathered generously on the top bun.

The result was WAY BETTER than any of the real filet-o-fish sandwiches I've had. The cheese was the game changer. Much better than what mcdonalds uses.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18916001
You don't have to prep this. It's just grocery shopping. That's why you use frozen patties instead fresh beef, or making out your own patties.
Even by spending more on the frozen patties compared to a roll of beef you're still going to come out ahead compared to McDonalds or any other fast food place.
Also since it is a frozen patty you aren't going to get your hands dirty making them out. Just throw them straight into the skillet. Use a paper plate to make less mess. You should be able to get by with one skillet and one tray to clean when you're done. You could even use some aluminum foil to not have to clean up the tater tot tray. Just place a sheet under the tots.

I'm not into any of this because of health reasons. I'm just a cheap ass who likes fast food but doesn't want to spend $6-12 on it when I can get the same thing either slightly better, the same, or slightly worse at home for $1-3.

A filet-o-fish is almost five fuckin' dollars bro.
My filet-o-fish at home was probably not even $2 and it was superior in every way.

>>18919803
for green/brown/black lentils: cook with water, bay leaf, garlic clove, and soup base/bouillion (optional). cook until tender, about 20 minutes.
drain and let it cool for a bit.
make into a lentil salad:
make a dressing (olive oil, sherry vinegar/lemon juice, pomegranate molasses/honey/maple syrup/dijon mustard)
then throw in a bunch of crap from your fridge: cheese (feta, gorgonzola, tiny mozzarella balls, etc), cherry tomatoes, chopped up olives/peppers/artichokes, dried fruit, cucumber, etc.
i eat this almost every single day for lunch.

>oven roast in pan until internal is medium rare
>deglaze roasting pan with red wine and chicken stock. add shit ton of oregano, red pepper, whatever you want really.

>let stock reduce a bit and place in fridge
>slice beef, reheat au jus and place beef slices in au jus until everything is warmed through
>serve on french bread bun

posts.com:
>>18919377
Not exactly a dish, but make your own bread.
Pizza dough is stupid easy:
4C. good bread flour
1tsp. salt
1½ C warm (115°F) water (I also put in 1 tsp. sugar)
1tsp. or packet yeast.
3Tblsp. olive oil or other liquid non-sneedgoyl(melted butter, coconut, etc.)
mix all together until mostly togeth, then turn out onto a flat, clean, surface
knead for about 8-10 minutes until smooth.
put back into the mixing bowl after coating the dough with a thin layer of oil
Cover and let rise in a warn place until doubled in size.(usually an hour)
That's it.
you now have enough dough for 1 pizza and 1 "Order" of breadsticks, or 2 pizzas.
I've been making my family sandwich bread lately as well by adding ½ C. milk/cream to 1 C. warm water and using melted butter instead of Olive oil.
All the shit for sale everywhere is now laden with Soy flour, sneed oil or other bullshit.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18920297
I'm only guessing here but likely to achieve a specific ratio of acid to sodium bicarbonate.

I agree that it's stupid. Usually the acid in baking powder is tartaric acid? "cream of tartar" I believe? I'm not sure why recipes don't just call for baking soda and cream of tartar it seems simpler.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18920297
Soda is much stronger than powder by weight, but it relies on the acidity of the rest of the recipe to work. And neutralizing the acidity of the finished product may in of itself be desirable.

But looking at that recipe specifically I don't see much reason to split soda and powder. I don't know much about pumpkin's pH specifically, but baking soda is typically reacted with things like chocolate, buttermilk or lemon juice; most foods are not acidic enough to really do much for baking soda. Maybe the recipe's designer has more specific knowledge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18920327
Baking powders sold anywhere these days are typically 2-stage powders, where one stage starts to react as soon as it's moisturized and seeds the batter with air pockets, then a second stage activates once the batter is heated and provides sustained air as the product bakes. I can 99% guarantee no commercial baking powder these days is (just) soda and tartaric acid. You're going to find aluminum pyruvates and all kinds of shit in there, but their purpose is to react at various stages and produce CO2.

>>18913140
Yes, here you go. I gotta sleep now. Later.

How to make rice:
1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.

>>18912771
I've got a Zojirushi rice cooker, and the rice always comes out perfectly.

What I like to do with it is I'll make the maximum amount of rice it will cook at once while I prepare some stir fry veggies/meat. Eat the stir fry over some rice, and throw the rest in the refrigerator for 3+ days.

See the key to making good fried rice, that every Asian mom/granny knows, is your cooked rice needs to sit in the fridge for a few days. Changes the consistency.

Then later on in the week I can take a cheap ass bag or two of frozen veggies, the kind of stuff they sell for $1-2 at the grocery store, eggs, and some chicken or pork (even leftovers work), and cook up some amazing fried rice.

For seasoning you can use the cheap fried rice seasoning packs, or you can just make your own mix of a bunch of different spices that sound good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18920504
Yea sure, aside from vermouth and mushrooms it's just a basic sausage stuffing
1.Boil giblets and neck in 4 cups of water with salt, pepper and bay leaves
2. Brown 2 lbs pork sausage, remove and add to 2 bags of sage&onion breadcrumbs, along with all but a couple tablespoons of the fat
3. Saute 2 bunches of chopped green onions, 3 stalks chopped celery, and 1-2 lbs chopped mushrooms in the pork fat. Deglaze with 1.5 cups vermouth and make sure to scrap up all the fond, dumping everything into bread crumbs
4. Strain out the water from step one, melt a stick of butter in it then add to the bread crumbs until they hold together on a fork but don't turn to paste
5. Chop liver and heart and throw them in too
6. Bake at 300 for 30 minutes, or stick in the bird

A later addition was to swap the pork sausage for Cevapcici if you can find it, which you often can't, and some of the snobbier family members believed in using plain breadcrumbs and seasoning themselves but I've never had issue with the preseasoned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18920381
>two departments dedicated to food?
If only it were that simple.

The USDA handles basically all animal products. The FDA handles everything else. When talking about shipping and importing/exporting, the DHS comes in to play. That's the federal level.

Additionally, every state has their own food control agencies as well. Until you hit a certain level of gross sales, you don't have to deal with the federal agencies usually, but at a certain point if you're successful and making food on a large scale, and shipping it across state lines it's possible that you will have to deal with 3 federal agencies as well as however many state agencies you're shipping to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What about the original greek cheesecake
https://greekcitytimes.com/2021/07/31/ancient-greek-cheesecake-2/

The cheesecake was invented in Ancient Greece.

By the fifth century BC, the ancient Greeks made the earliest known rudimentary cheesecakes or 'plakous', meaning 'flat mass.'

This early version of the cheesecake that we know today consisted of patties of fresh cheese pounded smooth with flour and honey and cooked on an earthenware griddle.

Centuries before New York City was even thought of, cheesecake was served to athletes at the first-ever Olympic Games in Olympia, Greece in 776 B.C as a source of energy.

The oldest surviving Greek cheesecake recipe was recorded by the writer Athenaeus in 230 AD.

The cheesecake recipe itself was pretty simple - pound the cheese until it is smooth, mix it in a brass pan with honey and spring wheat flour, heat the cheesecake "in one mass", allow to cool, then serve.

>>18918974
If you are eating at good restaurants, you're in for some interesting stuff. The dimsum is good at the bigger restaurants. But if you do decide to explore the city, just realize it will smell like pig shit/guts nearly everywhere. There's a spot called Big Wave Bay out of town a fair bit which has a lovely thai restaurant with really good coconut gelato. Get out of the city if you have access to a vehicle or can figure out their MTR system. HK is cool and relatively safe, but it is far more beautiful outside the city on the other islands. Best of luck on your trip. Consider Singapore also if you're going to be in that part of the world.
